title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 1 Corinthians chapter 1 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 1 Corinthians Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who is called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God according to 1 Corinthians 1:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul
questions.explanation: Paul is identified as the apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God in 1 Corinthians 1:1.

questions.question: To whom is the letter in 1 Corinthians 1 addressed?
options: The church of God at Corinth
The church of God at Rome
The church of God at Jerusalem
The church of God at Ephesus
questions.correctAnswer: The church of God at Corinth
questions.explanation: The letter is addressed to the church of God which is at Corinth according to 1 Corinthians 1:2.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:3, grace and peace come from whom?
options: God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Grace and peace are wished from God our Father and the Lord Jesus Christ in 1 Corinthians 1:3.

questions.question: What does Paul thank God for on behalf of the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 1:4?
options: The grace of God given to them by Jesus Christ
questions.correctAnswer: The grace of God given to them by Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: Paul thanks God for the grace given to the Corinthians by Jesus Christ as stated in 1 Corinthians 1:4.

questions.question: What enriches the Corinthians in all utterance and knowledge according to 1 Corinthians 1:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: They are enriched by Jesus Christ in all utterance and knowledge as per 1 Corinthians 1:5.

questions.question: What does Paul say the testimony of Christ was confirmed in among the Corinthians in 1 Corinthians 1:6?
questions.correctAnswer: Them
questions.explanation: The testimony of Christ was confirmed in the Corinthians according to 1 Corinthians 1:6.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:7, the Corinthians come behind in no what?
questions.correctAnswer: Gift
questions.explanation: Paul states the Corinthians come behind in no gift in 1 Corinthians 1:7.

questions.question: Who will confirm the Corinthians unto the end, that they may be blameless according to 1 Corinthians 1:8?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: The Lord Jesus Christ will confirm the Corinthians unto the end as stated in 1 Corinthians 1:8.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:9, by whom were the Corinthians called unto fellowship?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: God is faithful and called the Corinthians unto fellowship with His Son Jesus Christ as given in 1 Corinthians 1:9.

questions.question: What does Paul beseech the brethren to avoid in 1 Corinthians 1:10?
questions.correctAnswer: Divisions among them
questions.explanation: Paul beseeches the brethren to avoid divisions and to be perfectly joined together in the same mind and judgment in 1 Corinthians 1:10.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 1:12, some said, 'I am of Paul,' 'I am of Apollos,' 'I am of Cephas,' and 'I am of Christ.'
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:12 states that people identified themselves as followers of Paul, Apollos, Cephas, or Christ.

questions.question: True or False: Paul baptized many of the Corinthians himself according to 1 Corinthians 1:14-16.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul says he baptized only Crispus, Gaius, and the household of Stephanas and possibly no others in 1 Corinthians 1:14-16.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 1:18, the preaching of the cross is foolishness to those who perish but the power of God to those who are saved.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:18 explains the preaching of the cross is foolishness to those who perish but the power of God to the saved.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish _______; but unto us which are saved it is the power of God.' (1 Corinthians 1:18)
questions.correctAnswer: foolishness
questions.explanation: The verse states that the preaching of the cross is foolishness to those that perish as in 1 Corinthians 1:18.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:31, in whom should a person glory?
questions.correctAnswer: The Lord
questions.explanation: The verse says, 'He that glorieth, let him glory in the Lord,' emphasizing that glory belongs to God alone (1 Corinthians 1:31).

medium.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with divisions in their church. Based on 1 Corinthians 1, what biblical truth would you share about unity?
options: All should speak the same thing and be perfectly joined in the same mind and judgment
It is natural to have divisions and should be accepted
Each person should follow their own leader regardless of others
questions.correctAnswer: All should speak the same thing and be perfectly joined in the same mind and judgment
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:10 urges believers to speak the same thing and be perfectly joined together in the same mind and judgment, emphasizing the importance of unity to overcome divisions.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 1 teach us about humility in the context of God’s calling?
options: God chooses the foolish and weak things of the world to shame the wise and strong
Only the wise and mighty are called by God
We should boast in our own wisdom and strength
God’s calling depends on social status and power
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses the foolish and weak things of the world to shame the wise and strong
questions.explanation: Verses 27-28 show that God chooses the foolish, weak, and despised things to confound the wise and mighty, teaching humility in our calling and reliance on God’s power rather than human wisdom.

questions.question: A believer asks how to find peace in trials. What biblical truth from 1 Corinthians 1 would you share about God’s faithfulness?
options: God is faithful and will confirm you until the end blameless
Trials mean God has abandoned you
Peace comes only from avoiding problems
questions.correctAnswer: God is faithful and will confirm you until the end blameless
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:8-9 affirms God’s faithfulness in confirming believers until the end so they may be blameless, highlighting trust in God’s sustaining grace during trials.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1, what should be the focus of preaching and sharing the Gospel?
options: Christ crucified, not relying on human wisdom
Signs and wonders to impress people
questions.correctAnswer: Christ crucified, not relying on human wisdom
questions.explanation: Verses 17 and 23 emphasize that Christ crucified is the message preached, and relying on human wisdom would nullify the power of the cross, showing the importance of gospel simplicity and dependence on God.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 1 teach the believer about boasting and humility?
options: Boast only in the Lord, not in human achievements
Boast in your knowledge and gifts
Boasting is encouraged to gain respect
questions.correctAnswer: Boast only in the Lord, not in human achievements
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:29-31 instructs believers that no flesh should glory before God and that if anyone boasts, it must be in the Lord, emphasizing humility and dependence on God’s work rather than personal accomplishments.

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 1, Paul was sent primarily to baptize new believers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:17 clarifies that Christ sent Paul to preach the gospel, not primarily to baptize, indicating the priority of evangelism and preaching over baptism alone.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1 teach about the source of spiritual gifts in the church?
options: No one falls behind in any spiritual gift because they are enriched by Christ
Spiritual gifts are earned by personal effort
Only a few receive gifts to lead the church
Gifts are distributed based on social status
questions.correctAnswer: No one falls behind in any spiritual gift because they are enriched by Christ
questions.explanation: Verses 5-7 explain that believers are enriched in all utterance and knowledge so no one lacks any gift while waiting for Christ’s coming, encouraging contentment and unity in diverse gifts.

questions.question: A believer feels weak and insignificant. According to 1 Corinthians 1, what biblical truth can encourage them about their value to God?
options: God has chosen weak and despised things to nullify the mighty
Only the strong and wise are chosen by God
Weakness disqualifies you from God’s purpose
God values only the noble and mighty
questions.correctAnswer: God has chosen weak and despised things to nullify the mighty
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:27-28 teaches that God purposefully chooses what the world considers weak and foolish to shame the strong, affirming the value of all believers regardless of worldly status.

questions.question: True or False: 1 Corinthians 1 says that the wisdom of this world is superior to the wisdom of God.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Verses 19-20 affirm that God will destroy the wisdom of the wise and has made the wisdom of this world foolish, affirming the superiority of God’s wisdom.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 1 teach about the importance of fellowship among believers?
options: Believers are called into fellowship with God’s Son Jesus Christ
Fellowship is optional and not related to salvation
Fellowship depends on agreement in worldly wisdom
Only leaders are called to fellowship
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are called into fellowship with God’s Son Jesus Christ
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:9 states that God is faithful who called believers into the fellowship of His Son, highlighting the centrality of unity and relationship in the Christian life.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'But of him are ye in Christ Jesus, who of God is made unto us ________, and righteousness, and sanctification, and redemption.'
questions.correctAnswer: wisdom
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:30 states that Christ is made unto us wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption by God, showing the full provision of salvation and spiritual growth in Christ.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1 teach about the use of words in preaching the Gospel?
options: Preaching should avoid relying on the wisdom of words to keep the cross powerful
Words should be used to impress with eloquence
Preachers must use philosophy to persuade
Preaching depends on human wisdom for effectiveness
questions.correctAnswer: Preaching should avoid relying on the wisdom of words to keep the cross powerful
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:17 explains Paul was sent not to baptize but to preach the gospel, not with wisdom of words so that the cross of Christ would not be made void, pointing to the sufficiency of the gospel message.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to boast about their church leader. What guidance does 1 Corinthians 1 offer?
options: No one should say 'I am of Paul' or 'I am of Apollos', but all belong to Christ
Division is a sign of spiritual maturity
questions.correctAnswer: No one should say 'I am of Paul' or 'I am of Apollos', but all belong to Christ
questions.explanation: Verses 12-13 caution against claiming allegiance to human leaders, reminding believers that Christ is not divided and that they were baptized in His name, promoting humility and unity.

questions.question: How does 1 Corinthians 1 encourage believers regarding their spiritual gifts and knowledge?
options: Believers are enriched in all utterance and knowledge so they lack no gift
Gifts are only for personal benefit
Knowledge is more important than love
questions.correctAnswer: Believers are enriched in all utterance and knowledge so they lack no gift
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:5-7 teaches that the grace given by Jesus enriches believers in speech and knowledge so that they do not lack any spiritual gift, emphasizing the completeness of God’s provision.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1 say about God’s power compared to human strength?
options: The weakness of God is stronger than men
God’s power depends on human might
Men are stronger than God’s foolishness
questions.correctAnswer: The weakness of God is stronger than men
questions.explanation: 1 Corinthians 1:25 states that the weakness of God is stronger than men, highlighting the paradoxical strength found in God’s seeming weakness, encouraging believers to trust in God rather than human power.

hard.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 1 Corinthians Chapter 1.

questions.question: Who does Paul identify as having called him to be an apostle?
options: Jesus Christ through the will of God
questions.correctAnswer: Jesus Christ through the will of God
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states he was called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ through the will of God, emphasizing divine calling rather than human appointment (1 Corinthians 1:1).

questions.question: What is the main theme Paul encourages among the believers in verse 10?
options: Unity and agreement in mind and judgment
questions.correctAnswer: Unity and agreement in mind and judgment
questions.explanation: Paul beseeches the brethren to speak the same thing and avoid divisions, urging perfect unity in mind and judgment (1 Corinthians 1:10).

questions.question: Which group reported to Paul about the contentions among the Corinthians?
questions.correctAnswer: The household of Chloe
questions.explanation: Paul was informed by members of Chloe’s household regarding the divisions and contentions within the Corinthian church (1 Corinthians 1:11).

questions.question: According to Paul, which of the following was NOT a basis for the Corinthians' factionalism?
questions.correctAnswer: Being of Christ
questions.explanation: The Corinthians claimed allegiance to Paul, Apollos, Cephas, and Christ, but Paul questions if Christ is divided, implying the factions are misplaced (1 Corinthians 1:12-13).

questions.question: What reason does Paul give for baptizing only a few individuals in Corinth?
options: To avoid anyone claiming he baptized in his own name
He was not present long enough
Baptism was not yet fully established
He preferred to delegate baptism to others
questions.correctAnswer: To avoid anyone claiming he baptized in his own name
questions.explanation: Paul expresses gratitude for baptizing only a few so that no one could say he baptized in his own name, highlighting humility and avoiding personal glory (1 Corinthians 1:14-15).

questions.question: What was Paul's primary mission in Corinth as he states in verse 17?
options: To preach the gospel rather than to baptize
questions.correctAnswer: To preach the gospel rather than to baptize
questions.explanation: Paul clarifies that Christ sent him to preach the gospel, not to baptize, emphasizing proclamation over ritual (1 Corinthians 1:17).

questions.question: How does Paul describe the preaching of the cross to those who perish versus those who are saved?
options: Foolishness to them that perish; power of God to us that are saved
Mystery to the Jews; folly to the Greeks
A sign to the wise; a stumbling block to the foolish
questions.correctAnswer: Foolishness to them that perish; power of God to us that are saved
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts the perception of the cross’s message, highlighting its power to believers and foolishness to non-believers (1 Corinthians 1:18).

questions.question: Which Old Testament concept does Paul allude to when he says, 'I will destroy the wisdom of the wise'?
questions.correctAnswer: God's judgment against human wisdom
questions.explanation: Paul cites an Old Testament principle expressing God's intention to nullify worldly wisdom, emphasizing divine supremacy (1 Corinthians 1:19).

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Paul use to emphasize God's overturning of worldly wisdom in verse 20?
options: "Where is the wise? where is the scribe? where is the disputer of this world?"
"What is man that thou art mindful of him?"
"Have you not heard what the ancients said?"
questions.correctAnswer: "Where is the wise? where is the scribe? where is the disputer of this world?"
questions.explanation: Paul uses this rhetorical question to challenge worldly wisdom and show that God has made it foolish (1 Corinthians 1:20).

questions.question: True or False: According to 1 Corinthians 1:22-23, Jews and Greeks both accepted the message of Christ crucified without difficulty.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Paul explains that to Jews, Christ crucified is a stumbling block, and to Greeks, it is foolishness, indicating difficulty in acceptance (1 Corinthians 1:22-23).

questions.question: What paradox does Paul highlight about God's choice of people in verses 27-28?
options: God chooses the foolish and weak to confound the wise and mighty
God only calls the noble and strong
Human wisdom is superior to divine wisdom
questions.correctAnswer: God chooses the foolish and weak to confound the wise and mighty
questions.explanation: Paul articulates a paradox where God selects those considered foolish and weak by the world to demonstrate His power over worldly wisdom and strength (1 Corinthians 1:27-28).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: 'That no flesh should glory in his ______.'
questions.correctAnswer: presence
questions.explanation: Paul states that no flesh should glory in God's presence, emphasizing humility and God’s sovereignty (1 Corinthians 1:29).

questions.question: According to verse 30, what four attributes has God made Christ to us?
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption
questions.explanation: Paul declares that Christ is made unto us wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption by God, summarizing the spiritual benefits in Christ (1 Corinthians 1:30).

questions.question: How does Paul conclude his teaching about boasting in verse 31?
options: Let him that glorieth glory in the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: Let him that glorieth glory in the Lord
questions.explanation: Paul cites scripture to affirm that all boasting should be directed to the Lord, reinforcing humility and dependence on God (1 Corinthians 1:31).

questions.question: What is the significance of Paul mentioning both Jews and Greeks in his discourse on wisdom and faith?
options: To show that both cultural groups struggle with accepting Christ crucified
To highlight that only Jews accept Christ
To emphasize Greek superiority in wisdom
To indicate that the gospel is exclusively for Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: To show that both cultural groups struggle with accepting Christ crucified
questions.explanation: Paul contrasts Jewish desire for signs and Greek pursuit of wisdom to show both groups find the message of the cross difficult, underscoring the universal challenge of the gospel (1 Corinthians 1:22-23).

theological.title: 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 1 Corinthians Chapter 1 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:1, by whose will was Paul called to be an apostle of Jesus Christ?
questions.correctAnswer: God
questions.explanation: Paul explicitly states in 1 Corinthians 1:1 that he was called to be an apostle through the will of God, emphasizing divine initiative in apostolic calling. This aligns with Acts 9:15, Romans 1:1, and Ephesians 1:11 where God’s sovereign will directs ministry callings.

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1:2 identify the believers at Corinth as?
questions.correctAnswer: Sanctified in Christ Jesus
questions.explanation: The believers are described as sanctified in Christ Jesus, meaning set apart for God, which corresponds to the biblical doctrine of sanctification (Romans 6:19, Hebrews 10:10-14). It shows their holy calling in union with Christ.

questions.question: In 1 Corinthians 1:4-5, Paul thanks God for enriching the believers in what two areas?
questions.correctAnswer: Utterance and knowledge
questions.explanation: Paul acknowledges the enrichment of the Corinthians in all utterance and knowledge, highlighting spiritual gifts and understanding (Ephesians 1:17-18, Colossians 1:9-10). This reflects the transformative work of grace through Christ.

questions.question: What does Paul urge the Corinthian believers to do to avoid divisions, according to 1 Corinthians 1:10?
options: Speak the same thing and be perfectly joined together
questions.correctAnswer: Speak the same thing and be perfectly joined together
questions.explanation: Paul calls for unity and agreement to prevent schisms, emphasizing the biblical imperative for church harmony (Ephesians 4:3-6, Philippians 2:2-3). Unity is grounded in the same mind and judgment in Christ.

questions.question: Who are the four leaders or groups that some Corinthian believers claimed allegiance to, as mentioned in 1 Corinthians 1:12?
questions.correctAnswer: Paul, Apollos, Cephas, Christ
questions.explanation: The divisions were based on allegiance to Paul, Apollos, Cephas (Peter), or Christ, showing early church factionalism (cf. Acts 18:24-28, Galatians 2:9). Paul counters this by affirming Christ as the only head (Colossians 1:18).

questions.question: What rhetorical question does Paul ask in 1 Corinthians 1:13 to challenge divisions in the church?
options: Do you follow the law or grace?
questions.correctAnswer: Is Christ divided?
questions.explanation: Paul’s question 'Is Christ divided?' emphasizes the unity of Christ and that believers belong to Him alone, not to human leaders (cf. John 17:21, Ephesians 4:4-6). It refutes sectarianism inconsistent with the gospel.

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:17, what was Paul's primary mission?
questions.correctAnswer: To preach the gospel
questions.explanation: Paul states his mission was to preach the gospel, not to baptize, emphasizing proclamation over ritual (cf. Romans 1:16, Mark 16:15). He avoids relying on eloquence so the cross remains central.

questions.question: How is the preaching of the cross described in 1 Corinthians 1:18?
options: Foolishness to those who perish, but the power of God to those who are saved
The wisdom of men made perfect
A sign to the Jews and folly to the Greeks
A mystery hidden from ages past
questions.correctAnswer: Foolishness to those who perish, but the power of God to those who are saved
questions.explanation: The preaching of the cross is paradoxical: foolishness to unbelievers but divine power to believers, highlighting salvation’s countercultural nature (cf. Isaiah 29:14, Romans 1:16-18).

questions.question: Which Old Testament truth does Paul cite in 1 Corinthians 1:19 to show God’s action against human wisdom?
options: I will destroy the wisdom of the wise
Blessed is the man who trusts in the Lord
questions.correctAnswer: I will destroy the wisdom of the wise
questions.explanation: Paul quotes Isaiah 29:14 to illustrate God’s sovereign judgment against human pride and wisdom, affirming divine revelation over human understanding (cf. Job 5:13, Jeremiah 9:23-24).

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1:21 say about how God chose to save those who believe?
questions.correctAnswer: By the foolishness of preaching
questions.explanation: God chose what seems foolish to the world—preaching—to save believers, demonstrating the gospel’s power beyond worldly wisdom (cf. Romans 10:14-15, Isaiah 55:8-9).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:23, how is Christ crucified perceived by Jews and Greeks respectively?
options: A stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Greeks
A king to Jews and a philosopher to Greeks
A prophet to Jews and a teacher to Greeks
A savior to Jews and a myth to Greeks
questions.correctAnswer: A stumbling block to Jews and foolishness to Greeks
questions.explanation: Paul explains that Christ crucified offends Jewish expectations (stumbling block) and Greek intellectual pride (foolishness), revealing the gospel’s offense across cultures (cf. Isaiah 8:14, Romans 9:33).

questions.question: What does 1 Corinthians 1:25 teach about the foolishness and weakness of God compared to men?
options: They are wiser and stronger than men
They are equal to human wisdom
They are less important than human strength
questions.correctAnswer: They are wiser and stronger than men
questions.explanation: God’s so-called foolishness and weakness surpass human wisdom and strength, affirming God’s sovereignty and power in salvation (cf. Isaiah 40:28, Jeremiah 32:17, Romans 9:22).

questions.question: Who does 1 Corinthians 1:26 say are not many among those called by God?
questions.correctAnswer: Wise, mighty, and noble
questions.explanation: Paul points out that God’s calling often excludes worldly elites, highlighting God’s preference for the humble and weak (cf. James 2:5, Luke 1:52-53).

questions.question: What is the purpose of God choosing the foolish, weak, and despised things of the world as described in 1 Corinthians 1:27-28?
options: To confound the wise and bring to nought things that are
To bless the mighty and noble
To establish a new kingdom on earth
To replace the law with grace
questions.correctAnswer: To confound the wise and bring to nought things that are
questions.explanation: God’s choice serves to shame human pride and power, demonstrating that true glory belongs to God alone (cf. Exodus 7:3-5, Isaiah 10:15, Romans 11:33-36).

questions.question: According to 1 Corinthians 1:30, what has God made Christ to us?
questions.correctAnswer: Wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption
questions.explanation: Paul summarizes the comprehensive saving work of Christ as our wisdom, righteousness, sanctification, and redemption, emphasizing Christ as the fulfillment of all spiritual needs (cf. Jeremiah 23:5-6, John 1:14, Hebrews 7:24-25).
